content:
I found an unexpected solution by accident.  After I solved it in Ruby, I wanted to try a slightly different solution in Python.  I accidently found that you don't need to store a sorted answer or to rotate the piles to find the cycle distance.  

In example 3 Turn 2 and Turn 6 are cyclic because 3 2 2 and 2 2 3 are the same but you wouldn't be able to see that unless you rotated (or sorted, still not sure why sorting works and doesn't give you false positives).  

But the strange thing I found is that if you keep going Turn 7 [1 1 2 3] and then Turn 8 [1 2 4], now Turn 8 is exactly the same as Turn 4 without sorting or rotating. Now if you take the total turn count (8) minus the index of [1 2 4] (4) you end up with the answer of 8-4=4.  And this works for all the test cases.  Why?

I have changed the difficulty tag from easy to medium.

This puzzle can't be solved if you use neither the appropriate algorithm for cycle detection nor an efficient data structure for storing the previously seen configurations.

I agree with all JBM remarks. 
I must add the fact that the constraint on N should be changed to 30 (or at most 50)

Interesting.

What I found confusing:
- It's a card name, yet the card values are never used. It could just as well be a rock game.
- Your example makes it seem like we're supposed to keep the number of piles constant, whereas it doesn't seem to make much sense wrt the actual solution (or your author code)
- An example with a loop size of one is a bit light.
- Your validator 4 is titled "Test 8".

Interesting.

Edited the text, mainly revising the example format and adding 2 more examples. Also clarified the gameplay a bit, added a link to wikipedia entry and corrected the stub generator.
